item.media:title: Day 16: USA-3 finishes 13th
item.description: Mike Kohn's USA-3 sled, featuring Bill Schuffenhauer, Jamie Moriarty, and Nick Cunningham, raced to a 13th-place finish on Day 16 of the 2010 Vancouver Winter Games
item.media:description: Mike Kohn's USA-3 sled, featuring Bill Schuffenhauer, Jamie Moriarty, and Nick Cunningham, raced to a 13th-place finish on Day 16 of the 2010 Vancouver Winter Games

item.media:title: Highlights: Finland tops Slovakia for bronze
item.description: Finland came charging back from a 3-1 deficit in the third period to beat Slovakia 4-3 for the men's hockey bronze medal.
item.media:description: Finland came charging back from a 3-1 deficit in the third period to beat Slovakia 4-3 for the men's hockey bronze medal.

item.media:title: Medal ceremony: Four-man bobsled
item.description: The American bobsledders receive their gold medals from the men's competition during a ceremony at the Whistler Medals Plaza. The German team won silver and Canada took bronze.
item.media:description: The American bobsledders receive their gold medals from the men's competition during a ceremony at the Whistler Medals Plaza. The German team won silver and Canada took bronze.

item.media:title: Medal ceremony: Women's mass start
item.description: Justyna Kowalczyk, Marit Bjoergen and Aino-Kaisa Saarinen receive their respective medals for the women's 30km mass start held on Day 16 of the Olympic Games.
item.media:description: Justyna Kowalczyk, Marit Bjoergen and Aino-Kaisa Saarinen receive their respective medals for the women's 30km mass start held on Day 16 of the Olympic Games.

item.media:title: Razzoli wins slalom gold
item.description: Italy's Giuliano Razzoli wins gold on the men's slalom course on Feb. 27.
item.media:description: Italy's Giuliano Razzoli wins gold on the men's slalom course on Feb. 27.

item.media:title: Kostelic takes second silver
item.description: Croatia's Ivica Kostelic wins his second silver of the 2010 Games on the slalom course.
item.media:description: Croatia's Ivica Kostelic wins his second silver of the 2010 Games on the slalom course.

item.media:title: Day 16: Canada's Rush races to bronze
item.description: After crashing during two-man competition, Canada's Lyndon Rush raced to a four-man bronze medal on Day 16 of the 2010 Vancouver Winter Games.
item.media:description: After crashing during two-man competition, Canada's Lyndon Rush raced to a four-man bronze medal on Day 16 of the 2010 Vancouver Winter Games.

item.media:title: Myhrer skis to slalom bronze
item.description: Sweden's Andre Myhrer wins bronze on the slalom course on Feb. 27.
item.media:description: Sweden's Andre Myhrer wins bronze on the slalom course on Feb. 27.

item.media:title: Day 16: Germany wins four-man silver
item.description: In the final race of his career, Germany's Andre Lange lead his four-man team to silver, his sixth overall Olympic medal.
item.media:description: In the final race of his career, Germany's Andre Lange lead his four-man team to silver, his sixth overall Olympic medal.

item.media:title: Fan-swers: Lindsey Vonn
item.description: U.S. Alpine skier Lindsey Vonn takes the time to answer fan questions after winning two medals at the 2010 Vancouver Games.
item.media:description: U.S. Alpine skier Lindsey Vonn takes the time to answer fan questions after winning two medals at the 2010 Vancouver Games.

item.media:title: Day 16: Holcomb grabs Olympic gold
item.description: Steve Holcomb and his 'Night Train' squad -- Curt Tomasevicz, Justin Olsen, and Steve Mesler -- maintained a healthy lead throughout bobsled competition, finally ending a 62-year old four-man gold medal drought for the U.S. Here's a look back at their victorious performance during the final two runs on Day 16 at the 2010 Vancouver Winter Games.
item.media:description: Steve Holcomb and his 'Night Train' squad -- Curt Tomasevicz, Justin Olsen, and Steve Mesler -- maintained a healthy lead throughout bobsled competition, finally ending a 62-year old four-man gold medal drought for the U.S. Here's a look back at their victorious performance during the final two runs on Day 16 at the 2010 Vancouver Winter Games.

item.media:title: Medal ceremony: Men's curling
item.description: Canada receives their 13th gold medal of the Games after defeating Norway in the gold-medal match. Norway received the silver and Switzerland was awarded the bronze.

item.media:title: Day 15: USA-2's Napier crashes
item.description: John Napier of USA-2 was one of six sleds that struggled through the notoriously fast '50-50' at curve 13 during four-man competition on Friday, Feb. 26. The team finished 17th at the end of the first two heats.

item.media:title: Holcomb beats the odds
item.description: U.S. bobsled driver Steve Holcomb discusses overcoming Keratoconus, a degenerative eye disease that left him nearly blind, with Lewis Johnson and how such an experience has helped him develop as a pilot.

item.media:title: Day 15: Holcomb's USA-1 leads the way
item.description: Highlights from Steve Holcomb's momentous first two runs on Feb. 26, Day 15 of the 2010 Vancouver Winter Games. The Utah native's "Night Train" crew chats about their solid lead ahead of Canada's Lyndon Rush and Germany's Andre Lange.

item.media:title: Medal ceremony: Women's PGS
item.description: The snowboarders receive their medals from the women's parallel giant slalom competition. Nicolien Sauerbreij of the Netherlands won her countries first gold medal in a snowboarding event. Ekaterina Ilyukhina of Russia won silver and Marion Kreiner of Austria took bronze.
item.media:description: The snowboarders receive their medals from the women's parallel giant slalom competition. Nicolien Sauerbreij of the Netherlands won her countries first gold medal in a snowboarding event. Ekaterina Ilyukhina of Russia won silver and Marion Kreiner of Austria took bronze.

item.media:title: Medal ceremony: Women's curling
item.description: Sweden receives their gold medal in women's curling after defeating Canada in the finals. The rink from China was awarded their bronze medal.
item.media:description: Sweden receives their gold medal in women's curling after defeating Canada in the finals. The rink from China was awarded their bronze medal.

item.media:title: Medal ceremony: Women's slalom
item.description: Maria Riesch of Germany is awarded her second gold medal of the Vancouver Games. Austrian Marlies Schild won silver and Sarka Zahrobska of the Czech Republic received the bronze medal.
item.media:description: Maria Riesch of Germany is awarded her second gold medal of the Vancouver Games. Austrian Marlies Schild won silver and Sarka Zahrobska of the Czech Republic received the bronze medal.

item.media:title: Men's semifinal: Canada vs Slovakia
item.description: Canada will play Slovakia in the semifinal of the Olympic hockey tournament for a birth in Sunday's gold-medal game.

item.media:title: Medal ceremony: Men's 4x7.5km relay
item.description: The Norwegian, Austrian and Russian relay teams receive their gold, silver and bronze medals, respectively.

item.media:title: NBC Analysis: Four-man bobsled
item.description: John Papa and Duncan Kennedy discuss Steve Holcomb's lead halfway through the four-man bobsled competition and their predictions for Saturday's final two heats. Lewis Johnson also caught up with USA-2's John Napier, who was one of six sleds that experienced the wrath of the 50-50 curve on Friday, Day 15 of the 2010 Winter Games.

item.media:title: USA-SUI: Crazy end-to-end plays
item.description: The Swiss appeared to have scored, but the puck bounced off the post and out. Play continued to the other end, where Ryan Suter scored for the U.S. The goal was discounted because Ryan Kesler took a penalty in front of the net.

item.media:title: The path to Olympic silver
item.description: Billy Demong, Todd Lodwick and Johnny Spillane worked together for years, waiting for an Olympic payoff. With their team silver medal in hand, watch the journey they endured to get to that moment.

item.media:title: Jansen on losing a loved one
item.description: Speed skater Dan Jansen can relate with what Canadian skater Joannie Rochette is going through with the loss of her mother; he learned about the death of his sister just hours before he was about to compete in Calgary in 1988.

item.media:title: Tollefsen hit on Lubos Bartecko
item.description: Slovakia's Lubos Bartecko goes down hard after being hit by Norway's Ole-Kristian Tollefsen. Bartecko suffered a concussion and a laceration on the back of his head. Tollefsen received a 5-minute major penalty and a game misconduct.
item.media:description: Slovakia's Lubos Bartecko goes down hard after being hit by Norway's Ole-Kristian Tollefsen. Bartecko suffered a concussion and a laceration on the back of his head. Tollefsen received a 5-minute major penalty and a game misconduct.

item.media:title: Shea Weber's through-the-net goal
item.description: Shea Weber scored for Canada on a slapshot, but the puck went right through the netting and out the other end. Officials didn't rule it a goal and play continued, until it was reviewed at the next stoppage.
item.media:description: Shea Weber scored for Canada on a slapshot, but the puck went right through the netting and out the other end. Officials didn't rule it a goal and play continued, until it was reviewed at the next stoppage.

item.media:title: Phelps on London: 'It won't be eight'

item.media:title: Medal ceremony: Men's ski cross
item.description: The first ever Olympic medals in ski cross are awarded to the winners during a ceremony at BC Place. Michael Schmid of Switzerland won the inaugural gold medal. Andreas Matt of Austria won silver and Audun Groenvold from Norway got bronze.

item.media:title: Day 10: Bobsled bronze for Russia
item.description: Russia's Aleksandr Zoubkov raced to his second-career Olympic medal for two-man bobsled bronze on Feb. 21, Day 10 of the Vancouver Winter Game.

item.media:title: Medal ceremony: Women's 12.5km mass start
item.description: The medalists from the women's 12.5m mass start biathlon event are awarded their medals during a ceremony at the Whistler Medals Plaza. Magdalena Neuner of Germany was awarded her gold medal. Olga Zaitseva of Russia took silver and Simone Hauswald of Germany won bronze.

item.media:title: Olympic Classic: Canada vs. U.S.

item.media:title: Kesler seals game with empty net goal

item.media:title: Medal ceremony: Women's skeleton

item.media:title: Medal ceremony: Women's super-G
item.description: The medal from the women's super-G event were awarded during a ceremony at the Whistler Medals Plaza. Andrea Fischbacher of Austria won the gold medal and Tina Maze of Slovenia took silver, the first Olympic medal for both women. American Lindsey Vonn was awarded the bronze, her second medal of the Games.
